poem:
Title: "Awakening Echoes"

In the morning's paper, there's a murmur,
a woke whisper that piques and teases.
Not yet defined, yet staunchly firm,
its echo grows, weaves and pleases.
"Is it over?" cries the rancorous right,
but doubt only oils its gears,
and its lexicon of evening light
laughs at their futile fears.
Though birthed from chaos, it's anything but spent,
for woke isn't a fad, it's a ferment.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Woke’ isn’t dead – it’s entered the mainstream. Has it “peaked”, run its course before we’ve even properly agreed on what this endlessly controversial but somehow never quite defined social justice movement actually was? Though American rightwingers have been hopefully pronouncing its last rites for a while now, until very recently rumours of its death seemed exaggerated in Britain. Sure,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
